Japanese researchers just built an artificial blood compatible with all blood types.
Normally, when someone needs a blood transfusion, the blood has to match their type.
That's because red blood cells have tiny markers on them called antigens that act like ID cards.
If you get blood with the wrong ID, your immune system thinks it's dangerous and attacks it.
But what if there was a way to just erase those ID cards?
Well, that's exactly what these Japanese researchers did.
Their version of artificial blood has no antigens because it doesn't use real cells at all.
Instead, it uses something called hemoglobin vesicles, HBVs.
These are tiny fat-based bubbles filled with hemoglobin, the protein inside red blood cells that carries oxygen.
And since these vesicles are filled with hemoglobin, oxygen is still being delivered and circulated like normal.
It's just that because there are no real RBCs, there are no antigens.
So the immune system has nothing to recognize as foreign and nothing to fight.
These vesicles simply deliver oxygen without setting off any alarms.
But like anything else, it's not perfect.
Unlike real blood cells,
these vesicles can't carry carbon dioxide away from the body's tissues.
Something that needs to be removed to keep your blood from becoming too acidic and leading to breathing problems or even organ failure.
These bubbles also don't last as long as real red blood cells do.
Something that makes them useful only for short-term situations.
Still, despite the issues, the ability to safely deliver oxygen to anyone, no matter their blood type,
easily makes this a major breakthrough, especially for medical emergencies where real matching blood isn't available.
It might not be able to replace real blood altogether,
but it can surely buy something.
